The patient’s symptoms, including ear pain, otorrhea, facial droop, and granulation tissue in the ear, suggest a diagnosis of malignant otitis externa, which is commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Intravenous ciprofloxacin is an appropriate treatment for Pseudomonas infections, and a 6-week course is typically recommended for malignant otitis externa. Topical antibiotics are not as effective in treating this type of infection. Hyperbaric oxygen treatment may be considered in severe cases or as an adjunct to antibiotics, but it is not typically considered a first-line therapy. Surgical intervention may be considered in cases where there is severe necrosis or abscess formation, but it is not the initial recommended treatment.
